article.body: Stocks are looking up on Tuesday, beating back a bevy of concerns â Washington-Beijing tensions, the lack of a U.S. coronavirus stimulus package, and Europeâs virus resurgence. The optimists helped push the Nasdaq Composite COMP, +1.39% Â to log another record on Monday, while some see a new S&P 500 SPX, +0.87% Â high coming by the end of August. (The first intraday high in six months for the S&P was tapped early Tuesday). Away from the bull camp is Miller Tabak + Co.âs lead strategist Matthew Maley, who sees equities ripe for a near-term fall of 10% to 15%. An overbought stock market, notably within megacap technology stocks, uncertainty over a new stimulus plan, U.S.-China relations, and fears over an autumn pandemic wave should make investors uneasy, he says. But he has a more âconstructiveâ view about how the market will perform in the fourth quarter. In our call of the day, Maley suggests repeating an earlier-year strategy â âraise cash nowâ to take advantage of the next fall, and maximize profits in the rally later this year. âThose who followed our suggestions in Jan/Feb were very happy when March and April came aroundâ¦and we think theyâll be very happy over the next two months as well if they follow the same strategy,â Maley says in a recent note to clients. The Federal Reserve is key here. âThe Fedâs number one concern is the credit markets, not the stock market. Only a severe decline in stocks would destabilize the credit markets, not a 10%-15% correction,â he says. So, he expects the Fed will turn the spigots back open when that correction threatens to get more ugly, such as was seen in the first quarter. That could âlead the S&P to rally toward 3,600, but we also believe that will be very tough for the stock market to rally THAT strongly without experiencing a normal/healthy correction beforehand,â says Maley. History is also a factor, with the U.S. presidential election looming. He notes the stock market has rallied from Election Day (or shortly thereafter) until the end of the year on 10 of 12 past such occasions since 1972, with an average gain of 7.2%.
